channel.title: Mouse Listeners?

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“bundy, post:56, topic:269683”][quote author=qauters link=topic=355938.msg2741041#msg2741041 date=1239368230]

You can add multiple RS instances to a tabbed pane and flick between them no problem. The only reason why RSBot doesn’t have that functionality is because Speljohan thinks I’m a noob and hasn’t written a piece of code for a very long time.

Funny that RSBot2 did have tabbed botting, including a small realtime preview screen. So your argument doesn’t fully comply.
[/quote]

How much CPU and/or RAM does the preview screen take up? Just wondering.[/quote]
No idea, haven’t touched it in ages. Also my version of rsbot2 is on my lost hdd, so can’t access it atm.
But it doesn’t take so much cpu when you keep the refresh rate low. Also copying an image takes pretty low cpu compared to the calculations jagex has to do to render it.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

[quote=“Tenac, post:52, topic:269683”]jimmy5410, have you been able to solve a problem yourself yet? I’m not trying to stop you, but if it’s going to take this much help from us to make your own bot, I’m not sure if it will work out.

As for the color finding, once you can retrieve the BufferedImage of the canvas, it becomes easy. I see you’re doing bufferedImage.getRGB(x, y), but do you ever set bufferedImage to the client’s graphics? I’m just going to suggest you put a lot of thought into it and go through a lot of trial-and-error.

And the fact you even leeched some of that simple code makes me wonder how well you know java.[/quote]
Thank you for your concern.

I’ve created an image from the graphics component of the applet

Image image = getComponent().createImage(getComponent().getWidth(), getComponent().getHeight());

I’ve them created a BufferedImage with the width and height of the applet

BufferedImage bufferedImage = new BufferedImage(getComponent().getWidth(),getComponent().getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);

I’ve created Graphics for the BufferedImage

Graphics2D bufferedImageGraphics = bufferedImage.createGraphics();

and have them written the image to the BufferedImage

bufferedImageGraphics.drawImage(image, 0, 0, null);

I know Java well enough to finish this bot. Once I figure out the color finding, I know that I can finish it all up, although I thank you for being concerned

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @Tenac Tenac
item.description:
@Tenac wrote:

jimmy5410, have you been able to solve a problem yourself yet? I’m not trying to stop you, but if it’s going to take this much help from us to make your own bot, I’m not sure if it will work out.

As for the color finding, once you can retrieve the BufferedImage of the canvas, it becomes easy. I see you’re doing bufferedImage.getRGB(x, y), but do you ever set bufferedImage to the client’s graphics? I’m just going to suggest you put a lot of thought into it and go through a lot of trial-and-error.

And the fact you even leeched some of that simple code makes me wonder how well you know java.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:50, topic:269683”][quote author=jimmy5410 link=topic=355938.msg2738814#msg2738814 date=1239203723]
Well… I was working on some colorFinding methods, and I realized…

Couldn’t I simply use
Image image = getComponent().createImage(getComponent().getWidth(), getComponent().getHeight());
and paint that to the jframe after adding my own paint to it? THe problem is, that image is always null, and I have no idea why. Any thoughts?

Fyi, getComponent() is

    public static Component getComponent() {
	return(rs.getComponent(0));
    }

EDIT: Found this in the javadocs

an off-screen drawable image, which can be used for double buffering. The return value may be null if the component is not displayable. This will always happen if GraphicsEnvironment.isHeadless() returns true.

[code]isHeadless

public static boolean isHeadless()

Tests whether or not a display, keyboard, and mouse can be supported in this environment. If this method returns true, a HeadlessException is thrown from areas of the Toolkit and GraphicsEnvironment that are dependent on a display, keyboard, or mouse.

Returns:
    true if this environment cannot support a display, keyboard, and mouse; false otherwise
Since:
    1.4
See Also:
    HeadlessException

[/code]
[/quote]

you are trying to create the image when the applet/whatever else isn’t visible[/quote]
Oops… Lol

Alright, I think I’ve got this all down ( although my ColorFinding method is always returning false (-.-) ). Thanks for everybody’s help! I just need to know why the hell this can’t find a color…

NOTE: The for-loops I didn’t make myself, I found them @ sythe, although I easily could have.

My findColor:

[code] public static boolean findColor(Color color, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int xFound, int yFound) {

Image image = getComponent().createImage(getComponent().getWidth(), getComponent().getHeight());

BufferedImage bufferedImage = new BufferedImage(getComponent().getWidth(),getComponent().getHeight(), BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);
int colorint = color.getRGB();

Graphics2D bufferedImageGraphics = bufferedImage.createGraphics();

bufferedImageGraphics.drawImage(image, 0, 0, null);


for(int y = 0; y < y2-y1; y++)
	for(int x = 0; x < x2-x1 ; x++)
		if(bufferedImage.getRGB(x, y) == colorint)

return true;

return false;
}

[/code]

the Script

[code]import java.awt.Color;

public class clickColor {

int x, y;

public void start() {

System.out.println("Testing color finding methods...");


if(Bot.findColor(new Color(0, 0, 0), 0, 0, 500, 300, x, y)) {

	System.out.println("Found Color");
} else {

	System.out.println("Did not find Color.");

}
Bot.stop = true;
}

}[/code]

It can’t even find black (0, 0, 0)… This I have no clue whatsoever on what to do

Read full topic

and paint that to the jframe after adding my own paint to it? THe problem is, that image is always null, and I have no idea why. Any thoughts?

Fyi, getComponent() is

    public static Component getComponent() {

    }

EDIT: Found this in the javadocs

an off-screen drawable image, which can be used for double buffering. The return value may be null if the component is not displayable. This will always happen if GraphicsEnvironment.isHeadless() returns true.

[code]isHeadless

public static boolean isHeadless()

Tests whether or not a display, keyboard, and mouse can be supported in this environment. If this method returns true, a HeadlessException is thrown from areas of the Toolkit and GraphicsEnvironment that are dependent on a display, keyboard, or mouse.

Returns:
    true if this environment cannot support a display, keyboard, and mouse; false otherwise

    HeadlessException

[/code][/quote]

you are trying to create the image when the applet/whatever else isn’t visible

item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

Well… I was working on some colorFinding methods, and I realized…

Couldn’t I simply use
Image image = getComponent().createImage(getComponent().getWidth(), getComponent().getHeight());
and paint that to the jframe after adding my own paint to it? THe problem is, that image is always null, and I have no idea why. Any thoughts?

Fyi, getComponent() is

    public static Component getComponent() {
	return(rs.getComponent(0));
    }

EDIT: Found this in the javadocs

an off-screen drawable image, which can be used for double buffering. The return value may be null if the component is not displayable. This will always happen if GraphicsEnvironment.isHeadless() returns true.

[code]isHeadless

public static boolean isHeadless()

Tests whether or not a display, keyboard, and mouse can be supported in this environment. If this method returns true, a HeadlessException is thrown from areas of the Toolkit and GraphicsEnvironment that are dependent on a display, keyboard, or mouse.

Returns:
    true if this environment cannot support a display, keyboard, and mouse; false otherwise
Since:
    1.4
See Also:
    HeadlessException

[/code]

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

You need to hack into Canvas. Either make the RS class extend your own, custom canvas class which then extends Canvas and override getGraphics or hack into the Canvas class’s getGraphics method.

More advanced: Use reflection and change the canvas’s peer object. Either replace it with an instance of LightweightPeer or create your own ComponentPeer. This method requires the periodic checking of the Canvas instanced to make sure it hasn’t changed. Also you need to dispose the old peer.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

Well… I wasn’t thinking of making a tabbed bot in the first place.

So what your saying is I must create the paint before I grab the image?

[code]Thread drawthread = new Thread() {
public void run() {
Thread.sleep(1000);
while(true) {
try {
Component component = rs.getComponent(0);
Graphics g = component.getGraphics();
g.setColor(Color.GREEN);
g.drawString(“Testing…”, 15, 25);
Thread.sleep(10);
} catch (Exception e) {
System.out.println(“Error drawing paint.”);
}
}
}
};

drawthread.start();[/code]

is my current paint. Would that work?

If it works, then what exactly do I override getGraphics() with to do?

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Removing the applet from the component hierarchy serves no useful purpose. I haven’t looked at the Component and Container classes in detail but I would imagine that it would break some of the functions.

You can add multiple RS instances to a tabbed pane and flick between them no problem. The only reason why RSBot doesn’t have that functionality is because Speljohan thinks I’m a noob and hasn’t written a piece of code for a very long time. Preferring instead to make vague promises and make ad money and donations off the results. Keep away from making things static and you will be fine. Once the paint system is finished as described by either Taharok or myself Its then trivial to grab that image and resize to create an overview pane.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @Tenac Tenac
item.description:
@Tenac wrote:

jimmy5410:

Was I wanted to do was load RuneScape on the gui via a series of Images, rather then the Applet itself, so that you could turn Graphics off altogether, and still have a working bot.

that made me lol

Drawing the image on the frame isn’t what kills the CPU, it’s the actual RuneScape rendering code, which not updating your image won’t magically tell RuneScape to stop using it’s own rendering code.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

SMART is a bit of a mess, actually. Its purpose was to launch RuneScape and create a silent mouse on the canvas via scar, so that scar scripts can be executed silently. SMART does have a large amount of problems, and that’s not what I was looking to reproduce. Was I wanted to do was load RuneScape on the gui via a series of Images, rather then the Applet itself, so that you could turn Graphics off altogether, and still have a working bot.

Read full topic

rs.getContainer();

?

rs is the container.

You lost me somewhere. I like the idea of not adding the Applet to the frame, but rather adding an image of the Applet to the frame and adding the paint to that (as is done in SMART and RSBOT). I didn’t really understand the first step to doing that.
[/quote]

That’s not how RSBot works. RSBot does add the applet to the frame.[/quote]
Okay… then I would like to do it how BenLand did in SMART.

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“jimmy5410, post:36, topic:269683”]Taharok, I’ve already done that, but how do you use

getContainer

so that it doesn’t break once minimized?[/quote]

You are going to have to use the Applet instance wherever you are calling getContainer() instead of calling getContainer(). There are a few other solutions, but that one is probably the easiest (depending on what you are doing).

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:33, topic:269683”]What I was thinking of:

BotContainer.getGraphics:
Render the bot information on buffered image.
Get the parent graphics and draw buffered image on it.
Return the graphics of the buffered image.

Canvas.getGraphics:
Walk up the container tree until we hit BotContainer.
Get graphics on the bot container and transform coordinates based on the canvas’s relative position.
Return it.

Canvas.
Dispose the peer.

What I think you’re thinking of:
applet.getComponentAt(…).getGraphics().drawText(…);[/quote]

Interesting thought, but I was thinking more along the lines of:

Canvas.getGraphics:
Get buffer graphics.
Pass buffer graphics to bot PaintManager.
Get parent graphics and render buffer.
Return buffer graphics.

[quote=“jimmy5410, post:34, topic:269683”]Alright…

I’m a bit confused as to where I use getContainer… Using it on the applet ( rs.getContainer() ) gives a compiling error, so I assume that I’m doing something wrong? Help please…[/quote]

You get it from the client instance:

Class<?> client = Class.forName("client"); // or a variant way of getting the Class instance
Applet rs = (Applet)client.newInstance(); // calls client constructor and casts client instance to an Applet
// initialize and start applet...
// wait some time for applet to do enough of its startup procedure to continue...
Graphics g rs.getComponentAt(1, 1).getGraphics(); // example; should also be able to call rs.getComponent(0)

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Listeners?
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

What I was thinking of:

BotContainer.getGraphics:
Render the bot information on buffered image.
Get the parent graphics and draw buffered image on it.
Return the graphics of the buffered image.

Canvas.getGraphics:
Walk up the container tree until we hit BotContainer.
Get graphics on the bot container and transform coordinates based on the canvas’s relative position.
Return it.

Canvas.
Dispose the peer.

What I think you’re thinking of:
applet.getComponentAt(…).getGraphics().drawText(…);

Read full topic
